title: Insight Analyses Schema
description: Comprehensive foundational analyses for the INSIGHT phase - trend scanning, market understanding, competitive intelligence, SWOT assessment, and user/problem research that inform strategic opportunity identification and prioritization.
$comment: Insight analyses document research and intelligence gathering that precedes opportunity definition. Purpose: Create shared understanding of market context, competitive landscape, user needs, and strategic positioning before committing to specific opportunities. Use this schema during INSIGHT phase to synthesize research from multiple sources (customer conversations, market reports, competitive intelligence, analytics, user research) into structured insights that guide opportunity selection. Key sections: (1) Trends - external forces shaping the opportunity space (technology, market, user behavior, regulatory, competitive), (2) Market Definition - TAM/SAM/SOM sizing and segmentation, (3) Competitive Landscape - who we compete with and how we differentiate, (4) SWOT - internal strengths/weaknesses and external opportunities/threats, (5) User/Problem Research - target segments and problem/solution hypotheses. This is a living document: Update quarterly or when major market shifts occur. Track confidence levels for each section. Review before each planning cycle. Use insights to generate and validate opportunities in insight_opportunity_schema.json. Integration with EPF: Analyses feed into opportunity identification → opportunities feed into feature definitions → features feed into delivery plans. Quality over quantity: Better to have 5 well-researched insights than 50 superficial observations. Ground insights in evidence, cite sources, acknowledge uncertainty.

last_updated.description: Date when these analyses were last updated - track freshness to know when research is stale and needs refresh.
last_updated.$comment: Track last_updated to manage research freshness. Market conditions change rapidly - analyses older than 3-6 months may need refresh. Update when: Major market shifts occur (competitor launches, regulatory changes, technology breakthroughs), New user research is completed, Quarterly strategic reviews happen, Opportunities are invalidated (suggests analyses were wrong). Date format: ISO 8601 (YYYY-MM-DD). Use this to prioritize research work: If analyses are stale and driving active opportunities → urgent update. If analyses are stale but not driving decisions → low priority. Fresh analyses increase confidence in opportunity selection.

confidence_level.description: Overall confidence in the quality, completeness, and recency of these analyses - how much should we trust these insights to guide decisions?
confidence_level.$comment: Overall confidence reflects research quality across all sections. High confidence: Multiple evidence sources, recent research, comprehensive coverage, validated with users/market, team consensus. Characteristics: Primary research completed, competitive analysis up-to-date, market sizing from credible sources, user interviews representative. Use for: Green-lighting strategic bets, committing significant resources. Medium confidence: Some evidence gaps, research aging, partial coverage, directional but not conclusive. Characteristics: Mix of primary and secondary research, some sections incomplete, competitive intel from public sources only, user research from subset of target segments. Use for: Exploratory opportunities, validation experiments, incremental investments. Low confidence: Weak evidence, outdated research, incomplete coverage, speculative assumptions. Characteristics: Mostly secondary research, competitive intel from press releases, no direct user research, market sizing from rough estimates. Use for: Research priorities, hypothesis formation only - do not commit significant resources. Confidence informs decisions: High confidence + high value opportunity → proceed to NAVIGATE. Low confidence + high value opportunity → invest in research first. High confidence + low value opportunity → pass. Track confidence over time: Does research investment increase confidence? Are we building conviction or discovering problems?

next_review_date.description: Scheduled date for next comprehensive review of these analyses - when should we revisit assumptions and update research?
next_review_date.$comment: Next review ensures analyses stay current. Default review cadence: Quarterly for stable markets, Monthly for fast-moving markets, Ad-hoc when major shifts occur (new competitor, regulatory change, technology breakthrough). Set next review based on: Market volatility (fast markets need frequent review), Active opportunities (analyses driving decisions need fresh data), Research quality (low confidence analyses need sooner review). Review triggers: Scheduled date arrives, Major market event occurs, Opportunity validation contradicts analyses, Competitive landscape shifts. Review process: Check if trends still hold, Update competitive intelligence, Validate market sizing, Refresh user research, Adjust confidence levels, Document changes. Date format: ISO 8601 (YYYY-MM-DD). Use review dates to prioritize research: Reviews for active opportunities are higher priority than dormant research.

trends.description: Directional shifts across technology, market, user behavior, regulatory, and competitive dimensions that create context for opportunity evaluation.
trends.$comment: Trends inform opportunity identification by revealing: (1) Emerging capabilities (technology trends enable new solutions), (2) Market evolution (market trends indicate where value is moving), (3) User expectations (behavior trends show changing needs and preferences), (4) Constraints and enablers (regulatory trends define boundaries), (5) Competitive dynamics (competitive trends indicate strategic positioning needs). Good trend analysis: Identifies clear direction not just observations, Connects trends to opportunity implications, Provides evidence not just opinions, Assesses timing (is this trend accelerating or decelerating), Evaluates impact (which opportunities does this affect). Each trend should answer: What is changing? Why is it changing? When will it impact our space? How does it affect opportunity evaluation? Use trends to: Challenge assumptions about opportunities, Identify timing for opportunity validation, Spot convergence opportunities where multiple trends align, Avoid opportunities that run counter to strong trends.

technology.description: Technology shifts that enable new capabilities or render existing approaches obsolete.
technology.$comment: Technology trends include: Platform shifts (cloud to edge, mobile-first, AI-native), Capability breakthroughs (LLMs, computer vision, real-time collaboration), Infrastructure evolution (API economies, low-code, serverless), Integration patterns (composability, headless architecture). Focus on trends that: Enable capabilities users want but could not have before, Change economics of delivery significantly (10x cheaper or faster), Shift technical feasibility boundaries, Create new integration patterns. Examples: AI code generation reducing development costs 40%, WebAssembly enabling near-native browser performance, Real-time collaboration becoming table stakes in productivity tools, Vector databases enabling semantic search at scale. Impact dimensions: Does this enable a new class of solutions? Does this obsolete our current approach? Does this change competitive dynamics? When does this become mainstream?

trend.description: What technology shift is occurring and what capabilities does it enable?

timeframe.description: When will this trend significantly impact our product space? (e.g., 'happening now', '6-12 months', '1-2 years', '2-5 years')

impact.description: How does this trend affect opportunity evaluation and product strategy?

evidence.description: Sources supporting this trend: analyst reports, adoption data, competitor moves, technology releases.

market.description: Market structure and economic shifts that change where value flows and how customers buy.
market.$comment: Market trends include: Buying patterns (self-serve to enterprise sales, freemium to paid), Market consolidation (fragmentation to consolidation, vertical to horizontal), Value migration (features to platforms, products to services), Economic shifts (budgets expanding or contracting, ROI expectations changing). Focus on trends that: Change who makes buying decisions, Shift budget allocations significantly, Alter competitive landscape structure, Redefine value propositions that resonate. Examples: Enterprise buyers requiring security certifications as table stakes, SMB market shifting from perpetual licenses to subscriptions, Vertical SaaS consolidating features from horizontal tools, Economic downturn driving focus on efficiency over growth tools. Impact dimensions: Does this change our target buyer? Does this require different go-to-market? Does this shift competitive positioning? How does this affect pricing and packaging?

trend.description: What market shift is occurring and how is value moving?

timeframe.description: When will this trend significantly impact buying behavior?

impact.description: How does this trend affect opportunity prioritization and market approach?

evidence.description: Market research, customer conversations, sales data, analyst reports supporting this trend.

user_behavior.description: Shifts in how users work, communicate, and expect products to function.
user_behavior.$comment: User behavior trends include: Workflow evolution (asynchronous to real-time, desktop to mobile), Expectation shifts (manual to automated, complex to simple), Adoption patterns (training to intuitive, individual to team), Interaction models (text to voice, clicks to conversation). Focus on trends that: Change fundamental user workflows, Shift baseline expectations about what is possible, Alter adoption barriers or drivers, Redefine what constitutes good user experience. Examples: Remote work normalizing async collaboration tools, Users expecting AI assistance in every workflow, Consumer app simplicity setting B2B UX expectations, Mobile-first users unwilling to use desktop-only tools. Impact dimensions: Does this make our current UX obsolete? Does this enable simpler solutions to complex problems? Does this change onboarding requirements? How does this affect feature prioritization?

trend.description: What user behavior shift is occurring and what does it signal about changing needs?

timeframe.description: When will this behavior become mainstream in our user base?

impact.description: How does this trend affect product design and opportunity selection?

evidence.description: User research, analytics data, customer feedback, usage patterns supporting this trend.

regulatory.description: Legal, compliance, and policy changes that constrain or enable product capabilities.
regulatory.$comment: Regulatory trends include: Privacy requirements (GDPR, CCPA, data sovereignty), Security standards (SOC2, ISO, industry-specific compliance), AI governance (transparency, bias, accountability requirements), Industry-specific rules (healthcare, finance, education regulations). Focus on trends that: Create new compliance requirements affecting product design, Enable new capabilities through regulatory clarity, Shift competitive dynamics through compliance barriers, Change risk profiles for product features. Examples: GDPR forcing consent management into every product, AI Act requiring explainability in automated decisions, Healthcare regulations enabling telehealth platforms, Financial regulations requiring two-factor authentication. Impact dimensions: Does this require product architecture changes? Does this create barriers to entry or moats? Does this enable new market segments? What is compliance timeline and cost?

trend.description: What regulatory shift is occurring and what requirements or opportunities does it create?

timeframe.description: When does this regulation take effect or enforcement begin?

impact.description: How does this trend affect product capabilities, compliance costs, or competitive positioning?

evidence.description: Regulatory texts, legal analysis, industry guidance, compliance requirements supporting this trend.

competitive.description: Shifts in competitive landscape including new entrants, consolidation, and strategic positioning changes.
competitive.$comment: Competitive trends include: Market entry patterns (incumbents entering, startups disrupting), Feature commoditization (differentiation becoming table stakes), Business model evolution (pricing models, packaging strategies), Strategic positioning shifts (vertical specialization, horizontal expansion). Focus on trends that: Change what features are required vs differentiating, Indicate where competition is intensifying or retreating, Show how competitors are positioning against each other, Reveal undefended or over-served market segments. Examples: Incumbents adding AI features making it table stakes, Vertical SaaS companies expanding horizontally into workflows, Free tiers becoming expected in B2B tools, Open source commoditizing infrastructure categories. Impact dimensions: Does this make our differentiation obsolete? Does this indicate white space opportunities? Does this require repositioning? What features become table stakes vs premium?

trend.description: What competitive shift is occurring and how is the landscape evolving?

timeframe.description: When will this competitive dynamic materially affect our market position?

impact.description: How does this trend affect our differentiation, pricing, or strategic positioning?

evidence.description: Competitive intelligence, product releases, market research, strategic announcements supporting this trend.

key_insights.description: Synthesized insights derived from trend convergence, pattern recognition, and cross-dimensional analysis.
key_insights.$comment: Key insights emerge when you connect dots across multiple trends, identify patterns, or recognize implications that are not obvious from individual data points. Good insights: (1) Synthesize multiple trends (not just restate single trends), (2) Have strategic implications (affect opportunity evaluation or product direction), (3) Are actionable (suggest what to do differently), (4) Are non-obvious (reveal something not everyone sees), (5) Are evidence-based (grounded in supporting trends). Structure insights as: [Observation] combined with [Observation] suggests [Implication]. Examples: AI commoditization + mobile-first behavior suggests opportunity in AI-powered mobile tools that incumbents cannot match due to desktop-first architecture. Enterprise security requirements + SMB budget pressure suggests white space in security-compliant tools at SMB pricing. Remote work normalization + async collaboration tools suggests declining value of real-time presence features. Use insights to: Identify opportunity convergence points, Challenge assumptions about opportunities, Guide strategic positioning decisions, Surface blindspots in current thinking. Aim for 3-8 insights that meaningfully inform strategy - more insights dilute focus, fewer miss important patterns.

insight.description: Synthesized observation or implication derived from connecting multiple trends or patterns.

supporting_trends.description: Which trends from the analysis above support this insight? Reference specific trends by their key phrases.

strategic_implication.description: What does this insight mean for opportunity evaluation, product direction, or competitive positioning?

market_definition.description: Market sizing and stage characterization defining addressable opportunity scope.
market_definition.$comment: Market definition answers: How big is the opportunity? What portion can we realistically capture? When is the right time to enter? TAM (Total Addressable Market) = theoretical maximum if you captured 100% of all possible users. SAM (Serviceable Addressable Market) = portion of TAM you can serve with your product and business model. SOM (Serviceable Obtainable Market) = portion of SAM you can realistically capture in specific timeframe given competition and resources. Market stage affects opportunity timing: Nascent (undefined category, early experimentation), Emerging (category forming, high uncertainty), Growth (rapid expansion, land grab dynamics), Mature (defined players, feature parity), Declining (value migration elsewhere). Growth rate indicates momentum. Use market definition to: Validate opportunity size justifies investment, Assess timing (too early = expensive education, too late = commoditized), Size resource requirements realistically, Identify which opportunities have strategic scale potential.

tam.description: Total Addressable Market - theoretical maximum market size if you captured 100% of all potential users.
tam.$comment: TAM represents ceiling not realistic target. Calculate TAM to: Validate opportunity has sufficient scale, Compare opportunity sizes for prioritization, Communicate market potential to stakeholders. Common calculation methods: Top-down (analyst reports, industry data), Bottom-up (number of potential users × revenue per user), Value-based (problem cost × affected population). Example: Project management software TAM = 150M knowledge workers globally × $120 ACV = $18B. Be explicit about assumptions - geography (global vs specific markets), user definition (all knowledge workers or specific roles), pricing assumptions (current ACV or aspirational). Avoid: Unrealistic user definitions, Aspirational pricing without validation, Ignoring geographic constraints, Old data in fast-moving markets.

size.description: TAM size estimate with currency and timeframe (e.g., '$18B annual revenue opportunity', '150M potential users').

calculation_method.description: How was this TAM calculated? Include key assumptions and data sources.

sam.description: Serviceable Addressable Market - portion of TAM you can serve with your product, business model, and go-to-market approach.
sam.$comment: SAM applies realistic constraints: Product constraints (which user needs can you actually serve), Business model constraints (which customers can afford your pricing), Go-to-market constraints (which markets can you reach with your sales model), Competitive constraints (where can you realistically compete). SAM is smaller than TAM because: Not all users have problems your product solves, Not all users can access your distribution channels, Not all users fit your pricing/packaging, Not all geographies are serviceable. Example: If TAM is 150M knowledge workers but you serve only software teams (15M) in English-speaking markets (60% = 9M), SAM = 9M users. Define SAM by: User segment specificity, Geographic scope, Business model fit, Channel accessibility. SAM should be defensible - can you articulate why this segment is serviceable and others are not?

size.description: SAM size estimate showing realistic serviceable market (e.g., '9M software team members', '$1.2B serviceable revenue').

definition.description: How did you narrow TAM to SAM? What constraints did you apply and why?

som.description: Serviceable Obtainable Market - portion of SAM you can realistically capture in specific timeframe given competition, resources, and execution.
som.$comment: SOM is your realistic capture target. Factors limiting SOM: Competitive dynamics (incumbents with advantages, other startups competing), Resource constraints (sales capacity, marketing budget, product development speed), Execution risk (how well can you execute go-to-market and product), Time horizon (3-year vs 10-year capture rates very different). SOM should reflect: Current competitive positioning, Available resources for market capture, Realistic growth rates based on comparable companies, Market entry barriers. Example: If SAM is 9M users, realistic 3-year capture might be 180K users (2% share) = $21.6M ARR at $120 ACV. This assumes: 60K new users/year, 90% retention, 3 years to achieve steady capture rate. SOM validates opportunity is worth pursuing - if SOM is too small to justify investment, reconsider strategy or opportunity. Be honest - overly optimistic SOM leads to under-resourcing and missed targets.

size.description: SOM size estimate with timeframe (e.g., '180K users by year 3', '$21.6M ARR by 2026').

timeframe.description: What time horizon for this capture estimate? What assumptions about growth trajectory?

market_stage.description: What stage of evolution is this market in? Affects timing, competition, and go-to-market approach.
market_stage.$comment: Market stage profoundly affects strategy: Nascent (pre-category) - Opportunity: Define category and own it. Risk: Expensive education, uncertain demand. Strategy: Invest in education, land visionary customers, iterate quickly. Example: AI coding assistants in 2021. Emerging (category forming) - Opportunity: Capture market as it forms. Risk: Category may not materialize, standards uncertain. Strategy: Aggressive growth, land grab, establish positioning. Example: AI coding assistants in 2023. Growth (rapid expansion) - Opportunity: Ride growth wave, scale quickly. Risk: Competition intensifying, expectations rising. Strategy: Differentiate, scale GTM, land enterprise customers. Example: AI coding assistants in 2024. Mature (defined category) - Opportunity: Stable demand, predictable dynamics. Risk: Feature parity, price pressure, consolidation. Strategy: Efficiency, integration, vertical specialization. Example: CRM software. Declining (value migrating) - Opportunity: Consolidate position, harvest profits. Risk: Long-term viability uncertain. Strategy: Cost optimization, transition strategy, avoid new investment. Example: On-premise email servers. Match opportunity timing to market stage - emerging markets favor fast movers, mature markets favor operational excellence.

growth_rate.description: How fast is the market growing? Include percentage and timeframe (e.g., '40% CAGR 2023-2026', 'declining 5% annually').

market_structure.description: Segmentation of market into distinct buyer groups with different needs, behaviors, and economics, plus value chain analysis.
market_structure.$comment: Market structure reveals where value concentrates and which segments are most attractive. Good segmentation: Is mutually exclusive (segments don't overlap), Is collectively exhaustive (covers entire SAM), Reflects meaningful differences (segments have distinct needs/behaviors/economics), Is actionable (can target segments differently). Segment definition approaches: Demographic (company size, industry, geography), Behavioral (usage patterns, buying process, decision makers), Needs-based (jobs to be done, pain intensity, solution requirements), Economic (willingness to pay, deal size, sales complexity). Example software market segments: Enterprise (10K+ employees, annual contracts, security/compliance critical, multi-month sales, 6-7 figure deals), Mid-Market (200-10K employees, quarterly/annual contracts, feature depth matters, 2-3 month sales, 5 figure deals), SMB (1-200 employees, monthly subscriptions, simplicity critical, self-serve/low-touch, 3-4 figure deals). Each segment may need: Different product packaging, Different pricing models, Different go-to-market motions, Different messaging and positioning. Value chain analysis identifies: Where value is captured today, Which players control economics, Where inefficiencies create opportunity, How to position for value capture. Use market structure to: Identify most attractive beachhead segment (where to start), Assess expansion paths (how to grow), Understand competitive dynamics by segment (who competes where), Size individual segment opportunities, Identify value chain positioning strategy.

segments.description: Distinct market segments with unique characteristics, needs, and economics.

size.description: How large is this segment? Users, revenue potential, growth rate.

characteristics.description: What defines this segment? Key characteristics that distinguish it from other segments.

unmet_needs.description: What are this segment's distinct unmet needs or underserved jobs to be done?

value_chain.description: Key stages in value delivery and who captures value at each stage.
value_chain.$comment: Value chain analysis reveals: Where value is created and captured today, Which players have pricing power and why, Where inefficiencies exist (manual work, friction, waste), Where bundling/unbundling opportunities exist, How to position for value capture. Example value chain for project management: Requirement gathering → Tool selection → Implementation → Training → Usage → Analytics. Who captures value: Consultants (implementation/training), Software vendors (subscription), Integration partners (connectors), Training providers (education). Inefficiencies: Manual data entry (could automate), Context switching between tools (could integrate), Generic training (could personalize). Your positioning options: Own a stage (e.g., become the tool), Aggregate stages (e.g., tool + implementation + training bundle), Eliminate a stage (e.g., no-code setup removes implementation), Tax a stage (e.g., marketplace connecting consultants). Use value chain to understand: Who has power today and why, Where friction creates opportunity, How to capture value sustainably, What partnerships or acquisitions make sense.

stage.description: Stage name in value delivery process (e.g., 'Implementation', 'Usage', 'Support', 'Integration').

key_players.description: Who are the main players capturing value at this stage?

value_captured.description: What value do they capture? Revenue streams, customer relationships, data, market position.

inefficiencies.description: What inefficiencies exist at this stage that create opportunity?

competitive_landscape.description: Analysis of who competes for same customer budgets and attention, their positioning, and competitive dynamics.
competitive_landscape.$comment: Competitive landscape maps: Direct competitors (solve same problem, same approach), Indirect competitors (solve same problem, different approach), Substitutes (different problem, but competes for budget/attention), Potential entrants (not competing yet, but could). Competitive analysis should reveal: Where can we win? (segments/use cases where we have advantage), What advantages are defensible? (not easily copied), Where will competition intensify? (attractiveness draws entrants), How will competitors respond? (to our entry or growth). Barriers to entry protect markets: Network effects (value increases with users), Switching costs (hard to leave once adopted), Economies of scale (unit costs drop with volume), Brand/reputation (trust accumulated over time), Regulatory compliance (certifications, approvals), Integration depth (woven into workflows), Data/ML advantages (better with more data). High barriers mean harder to enter but more defensible if you succeed. Low barriers mean easier to enter but harder to defend - advantage must come from execution speed. Use competitive landscape to: Identify positioning opportunities (where competitors are weak), Assess defensibility of opportunity (can you build moats), Anticipate competitive responses (how will they react), Size required investment (what does it take to compete).

direct_competitors.description: Companies solving the same problem with similar approaches, competing head-to-head.

positioning.description: How do they position themselves? What customer do they target? What value prop do they emphasize?

strengths.description: What advantages do they have? Brand, features, distribution, pricing, ecosystem, etc.

weaknesses.description: What gaps or disadvantages do they have? Where are they vulnerable?

indirect_competitors.description: Companies solving the same customer problem but with different approaches or product categories.

how_they_solve.description: How do they address the customer need? What alternative approach do they use?

threat_level.description: How much do they threaten the opportunity? Low = different enough. Medium = some overlap. High = could block adoption.

substitutes.description: Non-consumption or manual alternatives that compete for same budget/time but solve different problems.
substitutes.$comment: Substitutes often underestimated: Excel as substitute for many SaaS tools, Manual processes as substitute for automation, Email as substitute for project management, Hiring more people as substitute for productivity software. Substitutes matter because: They set price ceiling (won't pay more than substitute cost), They define switching friction (substitute may be 'good enough'), They indicate willingness to pay (what do they pay for substitute). High substitute adoption means: Lower willingness to pay for new solution (substitute is working), Higher bar for 10x better (must overcome inertia), Opportunity to capture existing spend (not create new budget). Low substitute adoption means: New budget creation required (harder sale), Education needed (undefined category), Higher risk (will they pay at all).

substitute.description: What substitute approach exists? (e.g., 'Excel spreadsheets', 'Manual email tracking', 'Hiring coordinators')

adoption.description: How widespread is this substitute? What does adoption tell us about market maturity and willingness to pay?

barriers_to_entry.description: What protects incumbents or makes market entry difficult?

barrier.description: Describe the barrier (e.g., 'Network effects require critical mass', 'SOC2 certification takes 6+ months', 'Deep integrations with enterprise systems').

height.description: How difficult is this barrier to overcome? Low = months. Medium = 1-2 years. High = 3+ years or requires unique advantages.

market_dynamics.description: What forces are actively shaping this market? Dynamics are the underlying currents—shifts in buyer behavior, technology adoption patterns, regulatory changes, ecosystem evolution—that create momentum or headwinds. Each dynamic should explain what's happening and why it matters strategically.
market_dynamics.$comment: Market dynamics reveal WHY the market is evolving in certain directions and WHERE the energy is flowing. They're not static facts—they're forces in motion that create or destroy opportunity. Common dynamics: **Consolidation** (buyers preferring integrated suites over point solutions → harder for new entrants, incumbents gain), **Unbundling** (specialized tools beating all-in-one → opportunity for focused products), **Democratization** (capabilities moving downmarket → mass market opportunity, margin pressure), **Consumerization** (consumer UX expectations bleeding into enterprise → legacy vendors vulnerable), **Platformization** (ecosystems forming around central platforms → need integration strategy or become the platform), **Verticalization** (horizontal tools specializing by industry → compete on domain expertise), **Horizontal expansion** (vertical tools going cross-industry → risk dilution of focus). Good dynamics answer: What's changing? Why is it changing? Who benefits/loses? How fast is it happening? Strategic implications answer: Should we ride this wave or fight it? Does this open or close our opportunity? What capabilities do we need? Example: Dynamic: 'Knowledge work tools consolidating around Slack/Teams as central hubs (70% of teams now use one as primary workspace)' → Implication: 'We must integrate deeply with both platforms or risk becoming peripheral; standalone tools face friction'. Use this to understand timing (riding vs fighting trends), positioning (align with or differentiate from trends), capability priorities (what must we build to leverage dynamics).

dynamic.description: What force is shaping the market? Describe the change happening, who's driving it, and evidence of momentum.

implication.description: Why does this dynamic matter for strategy? What should we do differently because of it?

white_spaces.description: Where are the underserved needs, unmet jobs, or overlooked segments in this market? White spaces are areas where customer demand exists but current solutions fall short—creating opportunity for better approaches. Each white space should specify the gap, provide evidence that it's real, and assess the opportunity size.
white_spaces.$comment: White spaces are strategic gold—they reveal where you can win without fighting existing competitors head-on. They emerge from several sources: **Underserved segments** (groups ignored by incumbents—too small, too demanding, wrong fit for existing business models), **Unmet jobs** (tasks customers want done but no one solves well—workarounds indicate latent demand), **Overserved needs** (existing solutions too complex/expensive for many buyers—opening for simpler/cheaper alternatives), **Adjacent problems** (related needs that arise before/after current solutions—expand job scope), **Integration gaps** (friction between tools—opportunity to connect or consolidate), **Emerging use cases** (new workflows enabled by tech shifts—first-mover advantage). Good white space identification: **Gap**: What's missing or underserved? Be specific about the customer segment, job, or context. **Evidence**: How do you know this gap exists? Workarounds used, complaints heard, money being spent on substitutes, market research, user interviews. Multiple evidence points = stronger signal. **Opportunity potential**: How big could this be? Consider: How many customers have this need? How valuable is solving it? How much are they spending on alternatives? How quickly could we capture it? Example: Gap: 'Mid-market SaaS companies (50-500 employees) lack affordable, integrated customer success platforms—forced to duct-tape together CRMs, support tools, and spreadsheets' → Evidence: ['94% of mid-market CS teams report using 3+ disconnected tools', 'Average $40K/year spent on makeshift solutions', '"CS platform" searches growing 40% YoY among this segment'] → Opportunity potential: 'Estimated 15K companies in addressable segment, $600M TAM if we can capture workflow at $40K ACV. Currently zero purpose-built solutions for this segment'. Use this to: prioritize which opportunities to pursue first (evidence strength + potential size), validate hypotheses through evidence gathering, identify beachhead segments where competition is weakest.

gap.description: What's the underserved need, unmet job, or overlooked segment? Be specific about who has this gap and what's missing.

evidence.description: What evidence shows this gap is real and significant? Workarounds, complaints, spending on alternatives, research data, user interviews.

opportunity_potential.description: How valuable is this opportunity? Consider market size, willingness to pay, competition level, speed to capture.

strengths.description: What advantages do we have? Strengths are internal capabilities, resources, or attributes that give us competitive edge. Should be evidence-based and assessed for strategic value.
strengths.$comment: SWOT analysis forces structured thinking about strategic position. **Strengths** are internal positives—what we're good at, what resources we have, what gives us advantage. Good strengths are: **Specific** (not 'strong team' but 'experienced enterprise sales team with Fortune 500 relationships'), **Evidence-based** (metrics, customer quotes, competitive wins), **Strategically valuable** (explain HOW this strength helps us win). Common strength categories: Team expertise, Proprietary technology/data, Brand/reputation, Customer relationships, Distribution channels, Capital/resources, Speed/execution capability. Example: Strength: 'Deep domain expertise in healthcare compliance—3 team members spent 10+ years at Epic, Cerner' → Evidence: ['Successfully navigated 5 HIPAA audits', 'Healthcare customers cite compliance knowledge as #1 reason they chose us', '40% faster implementation than competitors'] → Strategic value: 'Gives us credibility to sell to risk-averse healthcare buyers and charge premium pricing for lower-risk implementations'.

strength.description: What's the strength? Be specific about the capability, resource, or advantage.

evidence.description: What evidence supports this strength? Metrics, customer feedback, competitive results, team credentials.

strategic_value.description: How does this strength help us win? What can we do because of it that competitors can't?

weaknesses.description: What internal limitations or gaps do we have? Weaknesses are areas where we lack capabilities, resources, or competitive parity. Should specify impact and potential mitigations.
weaknesses.$comment: **Weaknesses** are internal negatives—what we're not good at, resources we lack, disadvantages we carry. Honest weakness assessment is crucial for risk management and prioritization. Good weaknesses are: **Specific and honest** (face reality), **Impact-assessed** (how does this hurt us?), **Mitigation-considered** (can we address it? should we?). Common weakness categories: Team gaps (missing expertise/roles), Technical limitations (tech debt, scalability issues), Resource constraints (capital, time, team size), Brand/market position (unknown, perceived negatively), Distribution gaps (can't reach target customers), Operational immaturity (processes, systems, culture). Example: Weakness: 'No established security/compliance team—single engineer handles all SOC2, GDPR, and security reviews' → Impact: 'Blocks enterprise deals (88% of enterprise prospects require security review before contracting), creates risk of breach/non-compliance, prevents international expansion' → Mitigation: 'Hire dedicated security lead within 6 months ($150K investment), implement automated compliance monitoring ($30K/year), get SOC2 Type II certification by Q3'. Don't hide from weaknesses—they're where you need to invest or work around.

weakness.description: What's the weakness? Be specific about the gap, limitation, or competitive disadvantage.

impact.description: How does this weakness hurt us? What opportunities do we miss? What risks does it create?

mitigation.description: How can we address this weakness? Investment needed? Workarounds? Accept the limitation?

opportunities.description: What external favorable conditions or trends could we exploit? Opportunities are outside our control but available to capitalize on. Should specify how to exploit and prioritize.
opportunities.$comment: **Opportunities** are external positives—market trends, customer needs, competitive gaps, regulatory changes, technology shifts that create openings. They're different from white spaces (which are market gaps) and strengths (which are internal)—opportunities are external conditions we could leverage. Good opportunities: **External not internal** (it's out there in the market, not something we control), **Actionable** (we can actually do something about it), **Prioritized** (high/medium/low based on size, timing, fit with strengths). Common opportunity categories: Market growth/expansion, Competitor mistakes/exits, Regulatory/policy changes, Technology adoption shifts, Adjacent market entry, Partnership/acquisition targets, Customer segment expansion. Example: Opportunity: 'GDPR enforcement intensifying—EU fines reached €2.9B in 2023, 3x prior year. Privacy tools market growing 45% CAGR' → How to exploit: 'Position as compliance-first solution, launch GDPR Quick Start package ($15K, 2-week implementation), partner with EU consulting firms for lead generation' → Priority: 'High—timing is critical as companies scramble to comply, and we have technical capabilities built'. Note difference: Opportunity is GDPR enforcement (external event), Strength is our privacy technology (internal capability), White space is mid-market companies underserved by privacy tools (market gap).

opportunity.description: What's the external opportunity? Market trend, competitor gap, regulatory change, technology shift.

how_to_exploit.description: How can we capitalize on this opportunity? What should we do to capture value from it?

priority.description: How urgently should we pursue this? High = do now. Medium = plan for. Low = watch/consider.

threats.description: What external risks or adverse conditions could harm us? Threats are outside our control and could damage our opportunity. Should assess likelihood and mitigation strategies.
threats.$comment: **Threats** are external negatives—competitive actions, market shifts, regulatory risks, technology disruption, customer behavior changes that could hurt us. They're forces working against us that we didn't create. Good threats: **External not internal** (comes from outside, not our weaknesses), **Likelihood-assessed** (how probable?), **Mitigated where possible** (can we reduce impact? prepare contingencies?). Common threat categories: Competitive threats (new entrants, incumbent moves, price wars), Market threats (shrinking demand, consolidation, customer churn), Technology threats (disruption, obsolescence, security vulnerabilities), Regulatory threats (new restrictions, compliance costs, bans), Economic threats (recession, funding environment, customer budget cuts), Operational threats (key person dependencies, supplier failures). Example: Threat: 'Microsoft building competing feature into Teams—75% of our target customers already use Teams, could bundle for free' → Likelihood: 'High—Microsoft historically bundles to kill standalone tools, they have PM job posting for this exact area' → Mitigation: 'Focus on capabilities too complex for Microsoft to build (deep workflow customization), target IT teams not knowledge workers (Teams admin pain points), integrate so deeply that switching cost is high, build enterprise relationships before bundling arrives'. Threats don't mean give up—they mean prepare, differentiate, or pivot.

threat.description: What's the external threat? Competitive action, market shift, regulatory risk, technology disruption.

likelihood.description: How likely is this threat to materialize? High = probably will. Medium = might. Low = possible but unlikely.

mitigation.description: How can we reduce impact or prepare for this threat? Defensive moves, contingencies, pivots.

strategic_implications.description: What are the key strategic takeaways from this analysis? Implications connect analysis to action—they're the 'so what?' that tells us what to do differently. Each implication should synthesize an insight and specify resulting actions.
strategic_implications.$comment: Strategic implications are where analysis becomes strategy. They answer: Based on what we've learned about the market, competition, our position (SWOT), and opportunities—**what should we actually DO?** Good implications: **Synthesize multiple analyses** (connect dots across sections), **Are action-oriented** (specify what to do, not just what's true), **Are prioritized** (if unstated, high priority should be obvious from urgency/impact). Common implication patterns: **Market positioning** ('Competitor X dominates enterprise → we must focus on mid-market and build up'), **Capability priorities** ('Integration is a key barrier and our strength → double down on partnership ecosystem'), **Go-to-market** ('Buyers are skeptical of new vendors → need strong proof points before scaling sales'), **Product strategy** ('Adjacent opportunity in workflow Y is 3x our core TAM → explore expansion after achieving product-market fit'), **Resource allocation** ('Security weakness blocking deals → hire security lead is top priority'), **Timing** ('Regulation forcing change in 12 months → we have 6-month window to establish position before incumbents react'). Example: Insight: 'Market consolidating around platform players (Salesforce, HubSpot acquiring point solutions). Our strength is deep vertical expertise healthcare teams value. Threat: platforms will eventually build/buy our functionality' → Action: 'Position as must-have vertical layer that integrates with platforms rather than compete directly. Build integration partnerships with Salesforce/HubSpot within 6 months. Prepare to be acquisition target—our exit likely comes from platform player recognizing we solve healthcare better than they can build internally'. Use implications to: guide strategic planning, prioritize initiatives, communicate strategy to team/board, identify gaps between current state and where we need to be.

insight.description: What's the strategic insight from the analysis? Synthesize learnings across sections.

action.description: What should we do as a result? Be specific about decisions, priorities, or changes needed.

target_users.description: Detailed personas of target users with their contexts, problems, and jobs-to-be-done. These should be evidence-based and specific enough to guide product decisions.
target_users.$comment: Target users are the people who experience the problem most acutely. Good personas: specific role/context (not just 'manager' but 'engineering manager at 50-200 person SaaS companies managing 3-7 direct reports'), grounded in evidence (interviews/observations/data, not assumptions), focused on problems and jobs (not demographics), reveal decision criteria (what makes them choose/pay/switch). Persona elements: Role & context (what do they do? where? company size/stage/industry?), Goals (what are they trying to achieve in their work?), Current state (how do they work today? what tools? what frequency?), Problems (what's broken/painful/slow? how severe? how often? what's the cost?), Jobs-to-be-done (what 'job' are they hiring a solution for? when does this job arise? what outcome do they want?). Use personas for: Feature prioritization (what solves their top problems?), Positioning (speak to their context/goals), Go-to-market (where do they hang out? who do they trust?), Product decisions (which tradeoffs match their priorities?). Anti-patterns: demographic personas without problems ('25-35 year old urban professional'), assumed personas without evidence, personas too broad to be actionable ('anyone who manages projects').

persona.description: Name/label for this persona that captures their role and context

description.description: Detailed description of who they are, their context, and what makes them a target user

current_state.description: How they work today, their goals, context, and frequency of relevant activities

goals.description: What they're trying to achieve in their work that relates to this opportunity

context.description: Their work environment, team structure, tools, processes, and constraints

frequency.description: How often they encounter the relevant problem or need the job done

problems.description: Specific problems this persona experiences, with severity, frequency, and evidence
problems.$comment: Problems should be specific and evidence-based. Good problem: 'Spend 4-6 hours/week manually updating stakeholders via Slack/email → context-switching disrupts flow, updates out of sync, stakeholders miss critical changes → costs ~20% of productive time'. Bad problem: 'Communication is hard'. Include: what's the problem specifically? how severe? how often? what do they do today (current solution/workarounds)? what's the cost (time/money/opportunity)? how badly do they want it solved? what evidence proves this problem exists?

problem.description: Specific problem this persona faces, described from their perspective

severity.description: How severe is this problem for them?

frequency.description: How often does this problem occur?

current_solution.description: What do they use today to solve this? (tools, workarounds, manual processes)

workarounds.description: Specific workarounds they've created to deal with this problem

cost_of_problem.description: What does this problem cost them? (time, money, opportunity, stress)

willingness_to_solve.description: How motivated are they to solve this? What would they pay? What would they change?

evidence.description: Evidence that this problem exists and is severe (interviews, observations, data)

jobs_to_be_done.description: Jobs this persona is trying to get done (in JTBD framework sense)
jobs_to_be_done.$comment: Jobs-to-be-done: what 'job' are they hiring a solution for? Not features they want, but outcomes they need. Good JTBD: 'Keep remote team aligned on project status without disrupting flow → when working on complex multi-week initiatives with 5+ people → want everyone to know latest state, decisions, blockers without meetings/interruptions → current solutions (Slack/email/meetings) are either interruptive or quickly outdated'. JTBD elements: The job (what outcome are they trying to achieve?), When (what triggers the need for this job?), Desired outcome (what does success look like?), Current solution satisfaction (how well does their current approach work?).

job.description: The job they're trying to get done, expressed as an outcome not a feature

when.description: When does this job arise? What triggers the need?

desired_outcome.description: What does success look like? What outcome would make them satisfied?

current_solution_satisfaction.description: How satisfied are they with current solutions? What's missing?

product_problem_fit_analysis.description: Analysis of how well we understand the problem and how feasible a solution is
product_problem_fit_analysis.$comment: Product-problem fit is about understanding the problem deeply before building a solution. Three key dimensions: Problem clarity (do we really understand the problem? can we articulate it specifically? do users recognize it when we describe it?), Problem severity (how bad is the problem? what does it cost? how motivated are people to solve it? is it a vitamin or painkiller?), Solution feasibility (can we actually build a solution? do we have the capabilities? is it technically/economically feasible? can we deliver better than alternatives?). Good product-problem fit: crystal clear problem description users immediately recognize, severe enough that people will pay/change behavior, solution is feasible with our capabilities/resources. Poor product-problem fit: vague problem users don't recognize, low severity (nice-to-have), solution requires capabilities we don't have. Use this to de-risk: if problem clarity is low, do more problem interviews; if severity is low, might not be worth pursuing; if feasibility is low, need to acquire capabilities or pivot.

problem_clarity.description: How well do we understand the problem? Can we articulate it specifically? Do users recognize it?

problem_severity.description: How severe is the problem? What does it cost? How motivated are people to solve it?

solution_feasibility.description: Can we build a solution? Do we have the capabilities? Is it technically and economically feasible?

validation_status.description: Track which hypotheses have been validated, invalidated, or are still pending
validation_status.$comment: Validation status tracks our learning process - what have we tested and what did we learn? Good validation: specific hypothesis (not vague), clear validation method (how will we test this?), evidence-based status (what evidence supports validated/invalidated?), learning captured (what did we learn even if invalidated?). Hypothesis examples: 'Engineering managers spend 4+ hours/week on status updates' (validated via 12 interviews), 'Users will pay $49/month for async status tool' (invalidated - only willing to pay $29), 'Integration with Slack is must-have for adoption' (pending - testing with beta users). Validation methods: customer interviews, surveys, prototype tests, beta usage, market analysis, competitive research. Status: validated (evidence confirms hypothesis), invalidated (evidence refutes hypothesis - learn and pivot), pending (testing underway), partially-validated (true for some segments/scenarios but not others). Anti-patterns: claiming validation without evidence, ignoring invalidated hypotheses, not testing risky assumptions early.

hypothesis.description: The specific hypothesis being tested (make it falsifiable)

validation_method.description: How are we testing this? (interviews, prototype, data analysis, beta, etc.)

evidence.description: Specific evidence supporting the status (interview quotes, data, observations)

problem_solution_hypotheses.description: Hypotheses linking problems to potential solutions, with approaches to test them
problem_solution_hypotheses.$comment: Problem-solution hypotheses are testable statements about problems and solutions. Good hypothesis: links specific problem to potential solution, testable (can be validated/invalidated), specific enough to guide testing. Format: Problem (specific problem users face) + Hypothesis (our belief about how to solve it) + Test approach (how will we validate this?). Example: Problem='Engineering managers spend 4-6 hours/week manually updating stakeholders', Hypothesis='Automated status summaries from GitHub/Jira/Slack could reduce this to <30 minutes/week', Test='Build prototype that generates summaries, have 10 managers use it for 2 weeks, measure time saved and adoption'. Test approaches: prototype (build minimal version to test core hypothesis), concierge MVP (manually deliver the solution to test demand), smoke test (fake door test - see if people click), customer interviews (do they confirm the problem/solution?). Anti-patterns: solution-first (starting with solution not problem), untestable hypotheses (too vague to validate), testing too late (building full product before validation).

problem.description: The specific problem this hypothesis addresses

hypothesis.description: Our hypothesis about how to solve this problem

test_approach.description: How will we test this hypothesis? What's the MVP?

opportunity_convergence.description: Where multiple analyses point to the same opportunity (convergence increases confidence)
opportunity_convergence.$comment: Opportunity convergence is when different analyses (market trends, competitive gaps, user problems, white spaces) all point toward the same opportunity - this convergence dramatically increases confidence. Good convergence: opportunity emerges from 3+ independent analyses, supporting evidence is strong in each area, strength assessment weighs each source. Example: Opportunity='Async project status tools for remote teams', Supporting analyses=['Market trend: remote work growing 40% annually', 'User problem: managers spending 4-6h/week on status updates', 'Competitive gap: Slack/email synchronous, no async-first tools', 'White space: async collaboration category underserved', 'SWOT strength: team has remote work expertise'], Strength='Very strong - 5 independent analyses converge, each has strong evidence'. Convergence strength: Strong (4+ analyses, strong evidence in each), Medium (2-3 analyses, mixed evidence), Weak (1-2 analyses, limited evidence). Use convergence for: Prioritization (pursue opportunities with strong convergence first), Confidence (convergence = less risk), Storytelling (convergence makes compelling narrative).

opportunity.description: The opportunity that multiple analyses point toward

supporting_analyses.description: Which analyses support this opportunity? (trends, gaps, problems, etc.)

strength.description: How strong is the convergence? How confident are we?

strategic_tensions.description: Competing priorities or tradeoffs that must be navigated (both/and or either/or)
strategic_tensions.$comment: Strategic tensions are competing forces that create tradeoffs - you often can't optimize for both simultaneously. Good tensions: clearly articulated competing priorities, honest about the tradeoff (what do you gain/lose?), decision on how to navigate (lean one way? oscillate? resolve tension through innovation?). Common tensions: Breadth vs depth (serve many segments shallowly or few deeply?), Speed vs quality (ship fast and iterate or build it right?), Enterprise vs SMB (complex features for big deals or simplicity for volume?), Platform vs product (enable others or solve directly?), Short-term revenue vs long-term value (monetize now or build moat?), Generalist vs specialist (do many things okay or one thing great?). Navigating tensions: Lean (pick one side, accept tradeoff - 'We choose depth over breadth'), Oscillate (alternate focus over time - 'Enterprise in 2024, SMB in 2025'), Resolve (find way to do both - 'Tiered product: simple for SMB, advanced for enterprise'), Accept (live with tension, manage actively). Anti-patterns: Pretending tension doesn't exist, trying to do both without acknowledging tradeoff, not making clear strategic choice.

tension.description: What are the competing priorities or forces?

tradeoff.description: What's the tradeoff? How do we navigate it?

confidence_gaps.description: What don't we know yet? What uncertainties remain? What would increase our confidence?
confidence_gaps.$comment: Confidence gaps are the unknowns that matter - what would we need to know to be more confident in our strategy? Good confidence gap: specific (not 'we need more data' but 'we don't know if users will pay $49/month'), explains why it matters (what decision does it inform?), has clear path to close (what research/test would answer this?). Example: Gap='Unknown if async status updates reduce actual meeting time or just shift to other interruptions', Why it matters='Core value prop is time savings - if users just interrupt differently, benefit disappears', How to close='Beta test with 20 users, measure meeting time + Slack interruptions before/after for 4 weeks'. Prioritize gaps by: Decision impact (does this inform a major strategic choice?), Risk (if we're wrong, what's the downside?), Closability (can we actually answer this question?). Anti-patterns: Listing gaps without explaining why they matter, gaps too vague to address, not prioritizing (can't close all gaps, focus on highest impact).

why_it_matters.description: Why does this gap matter? What decision does it inform?

how_to_close.description: What research or test would close this gap?

next_analytical_steps.description: Concrete next steps to deepen our analysis and close confidence gaps
next_analytical_steps.$comment: Next analytical steps translate confidence gaps into action - what specific research/analysis do we do next? Good steps: concrete and actionable (not 'learn more about market' but 'interview 10 engineering managers at 50-200 person SaaS companies'), prioritized (high = do first, critical for strategy; medium = important but not blocking; low = nice-to-have), has clear owner/timeline. Example: Step='Conduct 10 problem interviews with engineering managers to validate severity and willingness to pay', Priority=high (informs go/no-go decision), Owner='Product lead', Timeline='2 weeks'. Prioritization criteria: High priority (blocks major decision, high uncertainty, can be done quickly), Medium priority (informs strategy but not blocking, moderate uncertainty, takes longer), Low priority (refinement not strategy, low uncertainty, can wait). Anti-patterns: Steps too vague to execute, no prioritization (everything is high priority), no owners/timelines (steps never get done).

step.description: What specific research or analysis do we need to do?
